speechtext: The House resumed from Thursday, April 9, consideration of the motion of Mr. Mazankowski that Bill C-56, an act respecting the control of government expenditures, be read the third time and passed.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Essex-Windsor has three minutes remaining in debate.

Madam Speaker, I think three minutes should be just about enough to point out to this government how the incompetence, irresponsibility and lack of sensitivity to the human damage which it is causing has come clear this morning in the dramatic increase in unemployment rates which has taken place in this country.
We see today an increase in unemployment rates to 11.1 per cent across this country. That is the highest level which we have seen in Canada since 1985. For adult males over the age of 25, we have a level of unemployment of 10.4 per cent, which is higher than in the recession of 1982.
What we have here is a government which has presided over the loss of 146,000 full-time jobs in this past month; 146,000 jobs in a single month. How can we possibly have any confidence in the economic management of this government? It is a government which has had no success in dealing with the deficit, no success in dealing with unemployment, no success in dealing with
poverty in this country, which has created increased inequality across this country, which has given tax handouts to its friends, as I discussed yesterday in the first part of my speech, and which continues to misunderstand the bitterness, the anger, the unhappy tragedy which is out there for Canadians across this country.
This is a government which is failing this country, failing it economically and, through that economic failure, failing to build this country for the future.
Yesterday, a promising development took place in Halifax with respect to constitutional change in this country. But those promising developments in constitutional change are not going to bring unity in this country so long as this government is creating two Canadas, one that is rich and privileged and powerful and another that, as these figures show today, is increasingly unemployed, increasingly powerless, increasingly left out of any kind of economic opportunity here in this country.
We cannot support anything that comes from this government pretending to be economic policy which in effect will have the result of continuing the tax handouts to large corporations and tax hand-outs to the rich, which created the economic mess which we see in front of us at the moment.
This government has failed. This bill is a sign of its failure. I hope this House will reject this piece of legislation on that basis.

Madam Speaker, I want to make a comment and put a question to the member who has just spoken.
Indeed, the unemployment numbers released this morning, as the member has suggested, show a dramatic increase month over month in the level of unemployment in Canada. We have been accustomed in this House to seeing an increase from 10.1 to 10.2 or 10.2 to 10.4, but I think Canadians have to wrap their minds around the reality that in one month, in just 30 days, unemployment in Canada increased from 10.6 to 11.1 per

cent. In one month another 100,000 Canadians went on the unemployment lines. During the period of one month, every day of that month more than 3,000 more Canadians a day went unemployed. If the trend continues, this very day that we speak, before the day is out, 3,000 more Canadians will be unemployed across this country. .Three thousand more notices a day are being given for jobs that have disappeared.
That is an incredible rate. That is a tragic rate of job loss in this country. What makes it tragic is that this job loss follows quickly on the heels of a budget introduced February 25, a budget that was advertised as a stand pat budget, a budget for recovery, a budget that would allow the natural market forces to do their work, to stimulate this economy and to put Canadians back to work.
I want to ask my hon. friend, who has been a finance spokesman for his party, a trade spokesman for his party, whether he believes the budget delivered by the Minister of Finance, the first budget delivered by this current Minister of Finance, can still in any way, shape or form be called relevant and appropriate, given the current economic circumstances and given what looks to be like the first tentacles of a vicious recession-not a recession, but a depression gripping this country.

Madam Speaker, I thank my colleague for his question.
We used to read stories as young kids growing up. One of my favourite stories was the story of the emperor who had beautiful clothes which were being spun for him, clothes which were supposed to dress him in splendour. It took one child to look at that emperor, start laughing and say: "He hasn't any clothes on," for the emperor to suddenly realize that he had been fooled.
I think that we have a situation in this country where a government has, with pomp and circumstance and splendour brought in a budget, pretending that that budget would do something about our economic problems. Ever since that budget has come out, there has been one piece of information after another which has said that the budget was threadbare, that the budget was ultimately non-existent and that the government stood there with absolutely nothing on in trying to deal with the problems of our country.
Just this past week we saw a reduction in housing starts. We see again, just this past week, reports of all sorts. The Royal Bank which gives to this government $50,000 or $60,000 a year in campaign contributions, nevertheless had to admit that the government's growth projections of 2.7 per cent were absolutely crazy.
In fact, the level of growth that could be expected in this economy was simply 1.4 per cent, less than half of what the government expected. We see today the final shock which I hope, because I care for these people who are being affected, will change this government's mind.
I hope that the shock of seeing this kind of dramatic, powerful rise in unemployment will force this government to change policy, force it to reduce interest rates significantly and force it to adopt a municipal infrastructure job plan, force it, through an economic recovery fund, to keep companies operating so that we keep people at work, force it to recognize that it has to extend the RRSP proposal to renovations so as to get more people back to work, force it to recognize that over the longer term it has to have an industrial strategy to get our industrial sectors back competitively throughout this country.
Across this country, there is a sense of despair which will be increased by the unemployment figures this morning. I plead with this government, please do something to respond. Show that you care, because people across this country need that sense of hope which they do not have in this government's present budget policies.

Madam Speaker, I want to participate in the debate on Bill C-56, because this debate is another example of how this government attempts to substitute substance with process.
The bill now before Parliament would ensure that the government, through legislative control, would follow the spending program that has been laid down by the government for a five-year period. Through this bit of smoke and mirrors, through this so-called legislative control of the government's spending program, the government attempts to convince Canadians that it is going to be responsible in how it spends taxpayers' moneys.
April 10, 1992

More to the point, the government is attempting to enforce its expenditure program not only on this current government but on succeeding governments. It is really a bit of nonsense. If the government wants to operate in a responsible fashion with respect to expenditures, then all the government need do is ensure that cabinet functions in a responsible way. If ministers do not function in a responsible way then all the Prime Minister need do is fire them.
With nearly eight years in power, to put forward legislation that purports to control expenditures and suggests that it is being fiscally responsible is pure nonsense. It is more propaganda. It is a deathbed repentance by a government that is on its last legs. It is a government that has fully the support of 10 per cent or 11 per cent of the population appealing to the 90 per cent that has left this government in terms of their political support. It is propaganda.
Speaking of propaganda, this morning I picked up a newspaper and I read the following headline: "Wilson Defends Spending Millions on Free Trade Success Stories". Canadians ought to think about that. The minister of trade is going to launch a multimillion dollar advertising campaign to tell Canadians about the great success of free trade.
Members opposite should be ashamed of themselves. You would want to have the face of a robber's horse to propose spending millions of dollars to say how good free trade is. Can you imagine?
Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition asked the minister of trade if, rather than have a propaganda campaign, would it not be better to use that money to help the hundreds and thousands of Canadians who have lost their jobs because this government could not do a good job in negotiating the free trade deal.
That was the question put by the Leader of the Opposition, and the answer from the minister of trade- and we need to hear this answer in the face of the unemployment stats this morning-was whether his hon. friend was saying that he is against providing advertising, providing information to Canadians, to let them know of the successes.
This morning the unemployment stats came out. Here is the story. We do not need advertising. It says that unemployment in Canada has gone from 10.6 per cent up to 11.1 per cent. It says that 1.6 million Canadians are

unemployed. It says that in excess of two million Canadians have given up even looking for work and have registered at the welfare agencies all across this country. They are not even looking any more.
We have upward of four million Canadians who are out of a job productive cycle in this country and the minister of trade, that sensitive, that caring, that plugged in, that realistic, that heart-beating Canadian from Bay Street wants to buy advertising to tell Canadians that there are some success stories.
Mr. Speaker, I am from Newfoundland, not Disneyland, and I am tired of this fantasy propaganda effort by the government opposite.
We have become like the people who used to watch the nightly news during the Vietnam war. We have become immune to the body bags. We have the numbers every month, 11.1 per cent, four million Canadians, 1.6 unemployed, and it does not register any more. We have become numb to the human face of unemployment. We have forgotten to care. We have been so battered and broken and bullied and pushed and pounded, month after month, by the tragic plight of unemployment in Canada that our nerve endings are numbed. We have stopped caring.
The government's response is that it is going to buy advertising. It is going to spend millions of dollars to tell those four million lost souls, to tell the man who has lost the dignity of a pay cheque, the woman who has been driven out of the work force, the children who have been dislocated and moved from their homes because the banks have grabbed up the mortgage and taken back the home, it is going to tell those poor lost unfortunate souls that there really are success stories, Virginia. There really is a Santa Claus. There are some people who are succeeding under free trade in Canada.
That is the most brutal, that is the most cynical kind of approach to government that one can possibly imagine. It is adding insult to injury. It is saying that this government believes that the level of intelligence, the level of conscientiousness the level of awareness, the level of sensitivity of the average Canadian can be defined by the cost of an advertising campaign.
This government is so convinced that the people of Canada live in little bunkers called houses and that they are so turned off by the plight of their neighbours, that if it can reach them by an ad on radio, television or in a newspaper it can communicate what is going on in this country.

April 10, 1992
Government Orders
Canadians are out in the streets talking to their neighbours, their brothers, their sisters, their mothers, their fathers, their cousins. They know that this economy is in a free fall. They know what no one dares to say and that is that we are not in a recession. This is not a recession we are living in; this is a depression.
Canada has entered a depression. An unemployment rate increase of 100,000 in one month. Three thousand people a day, each and every day for the last 30 days have been laid-off. That is not a recession. That is not slow growth. The country is in a depression.
The budget brought down by the Minister of Finance on February 25 as everyone well knows was an act of cowardice. It was turning away from the tough challenge of putting this country back to work.
We have heard many members of Parliament from all across Canada echoing that message. In particular we have seen many provincial members visiting the national capital coming from the poorer provinces which have had transfer payments for health care and education, CAP transfer payments. Some provinces were put on the Canada Assistance Plan unilaterally introduced by this government. They come to Ottawa and say: "My God, do you realize what is happening out there in the street, in real Canada?"
In just the last few days, I have had the opportunity of talking to members from the province of Nova Scotia. I spoke to Daniel Graham for Inverness South, Charles MacArthur for Inverness North and to Kenny MacAskill for Victoria, who are here in Ottawa making their case, telling the parliamentarians in this Chamber, telling members on the other side that it is time to recognize the real face of unemployment, the real face of human misery that is felt out there in the land. When members take the trouble to come from the other legislatures of this country and to convey that message, we have an obligation to listen.
What has happened in Canada in the last 30 days? What has happened since the budget was brought down in February across this land?
Let me talk about my own province. Unemployment in Newfoundland has now reached 20.3 per cent, a full 1.4 per cent increase. Not half a per cent, not a third of a per cent, but a full 1.4 per cent increase over one month. From 18.3 per cent in March 1991 to 20.3 per cent in
April 1992. How does that translate? It means that on the Avalon peninsula of Newfoundland, 18.8 per cent of the work force, those who have still bothered to register at Canada employment offices, are unemployed.
In the riding of my colleague from Gander-Grand Falls, who has spoken with such power, eloquence, passion and conviction about the people of his riding in this Chamber, it means that 22.7 per cent of the work force is unemployed.
In the riding of my friend the member for Bonavista- Trinity-Conception, it means that 20 per cent of the work force today are unemployed. That includes 1,000 fish plant workers in Catalina who lost their jobs because of foreign overfishing. Their jobs were closed down. My hon. friend spoke in this House with passion and with dignity on their behalf asking that their voice be heard and considered by this government. Just like the body bags in the Vietnam war it did not even crack a dent. It made no impact. It was like hitting the battle armour of an M-l tank. The news of those 1,000 jobs lost just bounced off and deflected. The government went straight ahead with its economic plan ignoring all of those people whose lives had been put on hold while this government continued to flounder and to flail and to offer more confusion, conflict and contradiction in its own ranks with the inability to deal with the reality of unemployment.
In western Newfoundland and Labrador, in my own riding, unemployment this month has gone to 23.6 per cent. There are 13,000 people who have registered and are unable to find work. This government's answer is: "Recovery is around the comer".
The Royal Bank announced just two days ago that its own projections for recovery in Canada were being scaled down from nearly 3 per cent, 2.7 per cent, to 1 per cent at best.
. The Royal Bank officially said that there will be no recovery in 1992 based on the current economic policy and plan of the government. It said that there will not be a recovery until 1993. Well the Royal Bank ought to get honest with Canadians. It should quit the soft sell. It should quit the mush. It should be honest and say that the country is moving into a long-term depression. The country is bleeding.
April 10, 1992

The same minister of trade who negotiated the free trade deal, who at the last second went to Washington in the dead of the night and signed on the dotted line on behalf of Canada on a free trade deal, the former Minister of Finance, the current minister of trade, now says: "You can trust me to sign and to negotiate the Canada-U.S.-Mexico deal because I am the guy who gave you the free trade deal".
What has been the result of the free trade deal? The result is that 300,000 highly paid manufacturing jobs in southern Ontario have gone. They have not gone for a week, or a month, or a year. They are gone forever because that manufacturing capacity, that manufacturing power base has been transferred to the United States. It is gone. They have not given a lay-off notice; they have levelled the factory. They have not told people to take a break; they have broken down the assembly lines and moved them south of the border.
The so-called most massive adjustment programs ever known in the history of the free world promised by the Prime Minister, adjustment programs and retraining programs, are nowhere to be seen in this country.
Canada needs a new economic program. Canada needs a recognition of how difficult times are in this country. I saw the news last night and the news was that the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs felt a renewed degree of confidence in the possibility of negotiating a constitutional deal. That is good news. I hope there is progress and that it stands up.
But by God, we have to realize in this place that the capacity of a country to heal itself constitutionally, to come together constitutionally, the capacity of a country to reach into its soul and find the generosity to unite is directly related to our capacity to put bread and butter on the table and to have the dignity of receiving a pay-cheque at the end of every pay period. They are inseparable.
Governments that believe they can negotiate constitutions in isolation of the human circumstance of the men and women of a country are governments that are living in fantasy land.
I feel, in a sense, that my voice is wasted here today because this Chamber is going to close for a scheduled break for the next two weeks and it is a Friday. It is the

last day of the week. It is the last day before we go away for 14 days. I ask myself whether anybody opposite is going to spend one moment of time, Mr. Speaker, other than you whom I know we can count upon, contemplating the real meaning of this dramatic increase in unemployment.
I wonder whether one minister opposite is going to go away and face up to the reality that the current economic plan has failed, that the current economic approach has failed and that Canada needs a new economic initiative. The country needs stimulation. The proposal of the Liberal Party of Canada, as articulated by the leader of the party, now needs to be given a chance.
We asked for a municipal infrastructure program. We asked for a program that would see one-third funding by the federal government, by the provincial governments and by the municipal governments. We asked that the multibillions of dollars of work that is out there waiting to be done and needs to be done, which represents an investment in the country, a retooling of our infrastructure, rebuilding the bridges, the roads, the water and sewer systems, the municipal infrastructure, that it be taken on and people be put back to work investing substantially in our future. We were not talking about painting the graveyard fence for the third time, we were talking about rebuilding the infrastructure of this country.
We ask again that that proposal be looked at. The Federation of Municipalities of Canada which originated that proposal will be meeting soon in Montreal. The mayors of all the great cities all across this country will be coming together. Once again, I expect they will be asking the government to look at that proposal to get this country working.
It is not hard to understand why the mayors are saying that. Look across the country. In St. John's, Newfoundland unemployment is 16.8 per cent; in Saint John, 12.6 per cent; in Sherbrooke, 12 per cent. In Oshawa, in southern Ontario, the heart of the manufacturing centre of this country, 11 per cent of the people are unemployed; St. Catharines, 10 per cent; Windsor, 11.6 per cent; Winnipeg, the riding of my friend and colleague, 11.7 per cent. In great Edmonton where every person from Cape Breton to Newfoundland went to find a job

Government Orders
when all else went wrong, unemployment is nearly 12 per cent. In Victoria, unemployment is 8.6 per cent.
This Prime Minister promised when he took power that he would change the face of Canada. Yes, Mr. Speaker, he has succeeded, he has changed the face of this country. It is a battered face, it is a bruised face, it is a shameful face, it is a face of a people who have lost their dignity and their hopes for a prosperous future. That is what this Prime Minister has done.
Canadians are telling this government, and certainly we on this side are telling this government, either face up to the reality of our circumstance, provide us with a realistic economic program, assist us, assist the municipalities and assist the provinces in getting this economy going, or move aside.
It should move aside because no government with just 11 or 12 per cent of the support of the people, not for a month or not as a consequence of a particularly bad political policy or a faux pas by the Prime Minister or a faux pas by the Minister of Finance but a government that has been sustained at 12, 13 or 14 per cent for a year has to ask itself whether or not it is fundamentally out of step with both the aspirations and the reality of the majority of Canadians.
This government is out of step. This government is dangerous to national unity. This government has brought this country to the edge of crisis. This government has to get with it and bring forward a realistic program.
If members opposite have one shred of compassion and belief in their country, if for one moment in their existence as politicians they can see beyond their partisan positions and see the position of the country for what it is, this government has to vacate office. It has to move aside. It has to call an election. It has to give the people of Canada a chance to elect a new administration of whatever stripe, of whatever make-up, to give this country a chance to work again.
In closing, may I say that if there is only one of that raggedy lot across the way who is maintained here as a voice of conscience for his people, I hope, Mr. Speaker, that it is you. Because when the fire storm comes, not many on that side are going to survive, and with good reason.

Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate my colleague from Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte for a magnificent, exceptional presentation to the House.
I want to ask him a question based on what he said a few moments ago about our rising today for a period of two weeks. I would like to put this question on the record. I want to ask the hon. member-and this should be something for the government to think about and the Canadian people to think about for the next two weeks. Why does the hon. member believe the government has behaved in such a manner?
The official statistics show that there has been a 50 per cent increase in the number of people who filed income tax returns in Canada earning between $100,000 and $125,000 a year who have non-taxable returns filed. Why is there an increase of some 40 per cent in the people who earn between $125,000 and $150,000 a year who filed income tax returns in Canada but do not pay one penny of income tax; a 40 per cent increase if they make between $150,000 and $200,000; a 30 per cent increase if they make between $200,000 and $250,000?
Here is the key one. If they make over $250,000 a year in Canada, why does the hon. member think that the Government of Canada made changes in our tax system? The official statistics from Ihxation Canada show a 30 per cent increase in the number of people making over $250,000 a year who filed income tax returns in this country last year and the year before who do not pay one penny of income tax.
I want to ask him why he thinks the government turned around three months ago, changed the law relating to trusts in Canada to allow them an increase for 30 years for all of those deferred capital gains taxes since 1972 owed by our biggest corporations and by our 20 or so billionaires in Canada. Why has that been deferred now for another 30 years?
Why did the government change the law relating to what very wealthy people can claim as entertainment and it places now as a limit in the Criminal Code of Canada that one can claim anything as long as it does not violate the Criminal Code of Canada, an 80 per cent deduction on the income tax returns of the wealthiest people in Canada?
April 10, 1992

I want to ask the hon. member why does he think the Government of Canada has done this?

Mr. Speaker, no rational person, and I do claim to be somewhat rational, no sane person, and I believe there is a degree of sanity in my approach to life, would attempt to give a reason that this government has favoured the privileged few at the expense of the hard-working many.
I could not pretend to rationalize or to give any rational, sane, reasonable, understandable or communicable reason that could be retained, examined and turned around in the light of day and found to be a solid reason that this government would do such a dastardly thing. Perhaps it is because it believes it has given such a large tax break in the February 25 budget to Canada's poor.
We have to be fair. My friend from Gander-Grand Falls would want to be fair. The government did give- he will recall we discussed it-a $2 a year tax break to a family of four with an income of $15,000. That is $2 a year, less than one penny a day, but it is $2 a year. The government did give a $7 a year tax break to a family of four with an income of $30,000. We must be fair and acknowledge that. It did give senior citizens just a few weeks ago a great big increase for this year, 37 cents a month.
We know the poor people of Canada are getting their share. It is only reasonable that if the wealthy millionaires and billionaires and the privileged corporate few are getting their multi-tens of thousands of dollars tax break, that senior citizens should get their 37 cents a month, that a family of four with an income of $15,000 should get their $2 a year. I suppose that is the rationale. Frankly, I do not understand it.

Mr. Speaker, I sit between the hon. members involved in the last discussion. Quite frankly, my colleague from Gander-Grand Falls always does ask skill-testing questions and I must congratulate my hon. colleague from Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte for giving an equally skilful answer.
I have another question for my hon. colleague from Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte. I wonder if he can answer this question. How, in his calculations, can a

government, any government, start with an x deficit and eight budgets and seven years later, after 30 income tax increases-
Thirty-three.

There have been 33 income tax increases, and goods and services tax bringing in billions and billions of dollars, we do not know yet exactly how much it is going to be, breaks for the rich just discussed, and all the extra income that it gets from individuals. The middle class now pays $1,620 a year more than it paid when that government came to power. After all this money coming in, the deficit is notx minus 1 orx over 2. It is still x, the same x as it was in 1984 and still there is no compensation that can be afforded. There are a measly few dollars for the people in a riding like Bonavista- Trinity-Conception who do not have any source of income, no UI, no nothing as a result of closure of a plant because of the mismanagement of the fishing industry. Can the member explain that?
Mr. Speaker, the member for Bonavista- Trinity-Conception, as always, puts a veiy good question. He makes a very powerful and persuasive point.
In the meantime, what about the national debt?

That is right. This government that has practised so-called frugality, this government that has told ordinary Canadians to tighten their belts until they can count their ribs outside their winter coats because they protrude that far, this government in the name of fiscal and monetary policy has put on a vice-grip, has planted the jackboots on the foreheads of all of those who are without privilege in this country, has more than doubled the national debt. It has taken the national debt, accumulated over 117 years by all previous governments of all political stripes and in a measly little eight years has doubled 117 years worth of debt. In eight years.
We have doubled the economy.

The member opposite, who goes out the door like an anxious crab scurrying after a bit of foul herring says: "We doubled the economy". He says that on the day that unemployment in Canada has gone to 11.1 per cent. I said earlier that members opposite had the face of a robber's horse. There is the robber's horse.

April 10, 1992
Government Orders
How have they done it? They have done it because while they were busy, so-called clamping down on expenditures, and busy putting the boots to the ordinary people of this country, they were equally busy feathering the nests of their friends. That is the simple truth. That is the reality.

In view of that answer, Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the hon. member whether he believes perhaps that is what is behind all of the recent changes to the Income Tax Act that benefit the very wealthy in Canada, as the hon. member said a moment ago, "to help their friends". We have seen several examples. The hon. member mentioned that a hairdresser recently got appointed to the board of the Federal Business Development Bank. Does the hon. member think that at that rate, the coiffeur of the minister of fisheries' moustache could be appointed to the United Nations? Is that the real reason why these changes took place? As the hon. member said a moment ago, it is to satisfy their friends.

Mr. Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to respond to that.
The hon. member has reminded me that the minister of fisheries, the member for St. John's West, a member of this cabinet, wants to practise the words of the premier of Newfoundland, so they say, "fairness and balance, a reasonable and just and proper approach to the expenditure of public funds". That is the bill we are debating today, Bill C-56. That is proper and reasonable expenditure of public funds.
The minister of fisheries for Newfoundland and Labrador, the minister of all the fishermen of Newfoundland and Labrador, 95 per cent of whom are not in the minister's riding, that minister of fisheries, the member for St. John's West, according to the estimates tabled in this House spent 70 per cent-seven zero-70 per cent of all the small craft harbours' budget for Newfoundland and Labrador in one constituency, the constituency of the member for St. John's West.
How can the hard-working fishermen who have a tough time making a living against the backdrop of foreign overfishing, who cling by their fingernails to the rocks on the edge of the Atlantic Ocean, scraping out and harvesting a living from the sea expect fairness when the minister of fisheries spends 70 per cent of the entire
budget for the entire province, for the entire land mass of all of Newfoundland and Labrador in one constituency, his own, a city riding? Shameful.

Mr. Speaker, I rise with some trepidation to join this holy trinity of Newfoundland members who have just in vivid and colourful language expressed the lament that all Canadians must feel on this black Friday for the plight of our nation and the sorrowful condition of so many Canadians.
I looked at the figures this morning to see in my own city of Winnipeg an unemployment rate of 11.7 per cent, up 20 per cent over last year. There are over 40,000 individuals unemployed in that one city alone.
I did not have to read the figures this morning to know what the situation was. I only had to visit high schools in my own constituency which had to put food banks in the schools themselves. We have now added a new form of curricular activity in the high schools of Winnipeg which is food banks to feed hungry students.
I did not have to read the figures to see that there are over 50,000 people on welfare, an increase of 25 per cent. Again, in my own constituency, I found that there was a two and a half year waiting list for people who have exhausted their unemployment insurance benefits to get into the training program.
I cannot ever forget the gall and blatant hypocrisy of a minister of employment who stood up in this House when asked these decent questions about what he is going to do for these people and said: "Don't worry, we are spending more money on training than we ever spent before," if you happen to be on the unemployment insurance roll.
What happens when you have 200,000, 300,000, or 400,000 Canadians who have exhausted their benefits and have nowhere to go? They do not get included in the calculations of that minister.
If you are a young person coming out of school and looking for your first job, you are not eligible for a training program. You have to wait for two or two and a half years. If you are a woman who wants to come into the work force to help support the family, a single parent mother, you do not get in the training program. You are on the waiting list.
April 10, 1992

By the way, officials in that riding have said: "We do not even take applications any more. We have given up. We do not even take names for the list because there is no point. Why let people go for frustration?"
Perhaps the argument is best summed up this way. At a meeting in my riding last night they said that recession is when your neighbour loses his job and depression is when you lose your job. Recovery is when this government loses its job.
That is going to be the only answer that Canadians are going to ask for. They understand that there is a bankruptcy, a total and complete failure of commitment, engagement or understanding about dealing with the plight of the unemployed in this country.
The government simply does not care any more. It will bring in a budget that totally ignores the economic reality of a country that is haemorrhaging in its loss of jobs and in fact aids and abets that loss of jobs.
I want to tell a little story. On Monday, I raised a question in this House of Commons to the external affairs minister asking why CIDA was giving a contract to an American firm to build steel grain bins which could be built by any number of firms in western Canada.
Now, I want you to listen to this carefully, Mr. Speaker, because you are a loyal son of the west. The minister wrote me a letter and with great clarity responded by saying that the reason we gave the contract to the Americans in Nebraska is because the costs were 30 per cent lower.
I showed the letter to the steel manufacturers in Canada. They did some comparison figures, and they recognized immediately what was happening was that the American firm was dumping its product into Canada.
So we have the incredible circumstance of a Canadian governmental agency using Canadian taxpayers' money, aiding and abetting an American firm to engage in an unfair trade practice by dumping its product below price in our country and taking away the jobs of Canadians while doing it.
And yet we have a government that is complacent, indifferent and could not care less. To top it all off, we

then have the minister of trade getting up and saying: "I am going to spend millions of dollars to tell Canadians about our success stories".
I suppose the number one success story in that glossy, multicoloured brochure will be how that firm in Nebraska took jobs away from Winnipeg because the Government of Canada procured products from them rather than from Canadians. I suppose that is the number one success story on which we are going to be spending Canadian government money to tell us how the system is working.
It is no wonder that we are facing 11 per cent unemployment when we have a government which does not even understand how to use its own resources, its own procurement, its own contracting, to give Canadians a helping hand.
To repeat and paraphrase the words of my good friend from Newfoundland, who in his own way paraphrased the words of Cromwell, you have done enough damage, it is time for you to go.
There are opportunities, there are initiatives. I look back into the historical record just to give one example. Back in 1983 when there was also a recession-we do not in any way try to cover the fact that there was high unemployment-but let me give you a contrast as to what was done at that time.
We used to have the NEED program, the New Employment Expansion and Development program. We put up $200 million, which was matched dollar for dollar by the municipalities, the provinces, the private sector and we put close to 60,000 people who had exhausted their UI benefits back into the work force. Tories across the way like to say that make-work projects do not work, but I will tell you how it worked.
Today in the city of Sudbury, the hills are blossoming with trees and grass because we put people to work on an environmental program to restore the environmental ecological fabric of that city.
In Thompson, Manitoba when the entire nickel mine went down the tubes for a full year we put 2,000 or 3,000 workers back to work fixing up the infrastructure of that city.

April 10, 1992
My good friend from Cape Breton is here. He knows full well that under that program we were able to build sewage and water treatment plants in his municipality.
Is that a waste of money? We just had a report from the Minister of the Environment yesterday which said: "My God, we have dirty, poisonous water in Canada, but we can't do anything about it". Well, we were doing something about it. We were putting unemployed people back to work to save the environment. That is what we were doing.

Mr. Speaker, as you know, next week is National Soil Conservation Week. Activities to heighten public awareness of new efforts within soil conservation will take place right across the country.
Farmers understand that good environmental practices make economic sense. In particular, they are promoting soil conservation by reducing tillage, looking more carefully at the chemicals they use, and taking marginal land out of production.
The new Land Management Assistance Program is now getting under way. This federal-provincial program is designed to help producers develop sound land management practices, practices that foster environmental sustainability.
Canadians across our country are concerned about environmental sustainability. Long-term protection of the health of our land, our water, and our air is of concern to farmers and is a high priority of this government.

Mr. Speaker, last August 9, Carol Valerio, a Canadian citizen and lifelong resident of this country, was legally married in the Dominican Republic. She immediately began making arrangements for her husband to join her in Canada only to find that officials predicted a processing time of no less than 1,000 days.
All too often Canadian citizens are discovering that the immigration system that they have been paying for all their working lives is unable to respond compassionately to their legitimate requests to be reunited with spouses living abroad.
I call upon the government to rediscover an appreciation for the integrity of families and act swiftly to ensure that the Valerios and other couples are not forced to spend their best years apart.

Mr. Speaker, this summer Veterans Affairs Canada and the
T.	Eaton Company are taking a unique medal display across the country.
The collection amassed over the decades by Veterans Affairs Canada features every decoration won by men and women of our Armed Forces. It features medals awarded to members of the Northwest Field Force and takes us through the Boer War, the two World Wars, all the way to our most recent decoration, the Canadian volunteer service medal for Korea.
This display is a part of our heritage. I congratulate the
T.	Eaton Company for sponsoring this cross-countiy tour. The Eaton family itself has a fine military tradition having personally financed the machine gun battalion in the First World War.
The medal display is Canadian at its truest and best. It is well worth a visit.

Mr. Speaker, in 12 days over 7,000 people from 100 countries will gather in Vancouver for Independence 92, the Interna-
April 10, 1992

tional Congress on Disability under the theme "Self-Determination by Persons with Disabilities".
This congress will reaffirm our commitment to full participation and the integration of persons with disabilities into the community.
The minister responsible for disabled persons plans to use this event to announce upcoming omnibus legislation on disability issues. Considering that the government has had about seven and one-half years to prepare for this, we expect more than just an announcement of upcoming legislation. We would like to see the bill itself.
I also call on the government to overhaul legislation affecting disabled persons in such areas as social assistance, health, education, and taxes.
Canadians with disabilities believe these measures are long overdue and hope that this government is fully committed to making full participation a reality.

Mr. Speaker, the Canadian government has forfeited world leadership in the health battle against smoking by allowing tobacco companies to export cheap cigarettes to the U.S. for the primary purpose of smuggling.
Canadians wanting positive action to reduce smoking must now look to countries like Australia which has now banned all cigarette advertising in promotion of sports and cultural efforts.
The Australian government took this action after research showed that tobacco advertising induced children age 10 to 12 to start smoking. A full 80 per cent of children in this age group believe cigarette advertisements encourage them to smoke.
The Australian High Court has ruled that sports and culture sponsorships are used for advertising opportunities not benevolence.
Where does our federal government stand in regard to the health of children age 10 to 12 who are now being actively recruited as smokers of tomorrow? Let us regain world leadership in the battle against smoking and adopt the same advertising ban as Australia.

subtopic: INTERNATIONAL PEE-WEE HOCKEY TOURNAMENT IN QUEBEC CITY

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
subtopic: INTERNATIONAL PEE-WEE HOCKEY TOURNAMENT IN QUEBEC CITY
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, again considering the huge success of the International Pee-Wee Hockey Tournament at the Colisee in Quebec City last February, it seems important to mention that this 33rd edition of the tournament was a unique opportunity for some 2,000 twelve and thirteen-year olds representing 105 pee-wee clubs to get together in a spirit of friendly sporting competition.
This unique event, the world's most prestigious for minor hockey, gave 193,546 visitors and 5 million ice hockey fans who had already been to the Quebec Colisee a chance to appreciate how talented the new generation is.
Finally, Mr. Speaker, I must point out that Quebec City paid tribute to all the tournament volunteers by raising a giant banner in homage to them on the roof of the Colisee. The 34th edition will be something not to miss next year.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to advise this House and residents of Prince Edward Island that the Liberal House of Commons-Senate Committee on Youth will be travelling to Prince Edward Island on April 22.
This committee was set up by our leader to co-operatively design a plan of action to address the problems faced by our young people.
There are 400,000 young people unemployed in Canada at this time. Thirty-eight per cent of Canadian adults cannot meet everyday literacy requirements. We have a 30 per cent high school drop-out rate. It is obvious that something is going wrong.
We must provide our youth with the necessary education, knowledge and skills to compete in the increasingly international economy. We must also ensure that the country that we turn over to our youth in the years ahead is united, economically competitive and environmentally sound.

April 10, 1992
I encourage all Islanders to participate in this initiative either by making a presentation or by attending the hearings as an observer.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as you know, 60 bantam hockey teams from all across Canada are participating this week in the Unity Hockey Tournament in Toronto. For many, this week has provided their first plane trip, their first visit to Canada's largest city, and certainly their first and probably only opportunity to play hockey in historic Maple Leaf Gardens.
As you would understand, Mr. Speaker, I was thrilled to be able to stand at centre ice to drop the puck at the beginning of the game between the Brandon Bantam Wheat Kings and the Ste. Foy Gouverneurs. But I was even more excited to learn that accompanying parents were encouraging late evening hotel room discussions involving young players from across this land on the theme of national unity.
Our collective thanks are owed to many, including the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, the Minister of National Defence and particularly to the MP for Broadview-Greenwood who initially proposed this idea.
In fact, without the organizational skills and tireless efforts of Dennis Mills, Diane Scharf and others, this tremendous week which in itself is a testament to the value of a united Canada could not have occurred and many of us would have been the losers as a result.

Mr. Speaker, on three separate occasions in this House in the past few weeks I have asked questions to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and the Minister of Employment and Immigration seeking a compensation package for those people who have not been looked after as a result of the recent northern cod reduction and specifically the closure of the processing plant in Catali-na-Port Union.
I met last weekend with families who are among the hundreds of people who have not yet had any form of compensation. It is no good for the government to talk about the $584 million or to talk about the $57 million in compensation for the two previous years, as it always does, if these 100 families cannot get their hands on any of it.
I am going to appeal to the compassion of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans for his fellow Newfoundlanders who have been severely hurt by this tragic turn of events in the north Atlantic fisheries.
When can I expect a straightforward reply that yes, there is a minister for Newfoundland who cares and that compensation will be forthcoming while there is still some dignity and hope remaining.

Mr. Speaker, with the government's report yesterday on the state of Canada's environment, among the points mentioned in the selected highlights is the following:
Despite its remoteness, the Arctic has not escaped pollution from
southern Canada, the United States, and even Europe and Asia.
Lead, PCBs, pesticides and other contaminants are found in the air,
water, soils and wildlife of the region, carried by winds high in the
atmosphere, as well as by north-flowing rivers and ocean currents.
What is the government doing about this? It says action is underway to accurately determine the sources of the contaminants. We know where the contaminants are coming from. It is not time for more studies, it is time for action.
The government's approach reminds me of Ronald Reagan: "Let us check trees to see if there is acid rain". Let us do something about it now.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in its examination of cross-border shopping, the federal government must give careful consideration to the Ernst and Young study done for Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. Two findings of the October 1990 study are of particular importance:
April 10, 1992

(1)	That 43 per cent of the survey respondents claimed that the motivation of their last same-day shopping trip was for specific purposes, like the purchase of gasoline or milk;
(2)	That 68 per cent of those surveyed said that if gasoline was comparable in price with that in the U.S. they would not cross-border shop.
In light of these findings, all governments must consider the fact that the current level of taxation on gasoline, both federal and provincial, represents some 85 per cent of the price differential of gasoline.
Together gasoline taxes constitute 40 per cent of the retail price. In this case taxation is making us uncompetitive. I think the federal government must entertain and examine innovative proposals which would seek to address this tax-induced competitive inequity.

Mr. Speaker, on February 13 last in the Thompson case, the Supreme Court of Canada confirmed the danger pointed out two years ago by a committee of this House.
The appeal process for public servants and others denied security clearance by departments is toothless and has no authority according to the Supreme Court.
In the words of the chairman of the Security Intelligence Review Committee: "Canadians have had their rights significantly reduced".
A special committee of this House had recommended that section 52 of the CSIS act be amended to make security clearance review decisions binding on department heads but the government said no. Now the Supreme Court has confirmed the worst: Canadians have virtually no rights on appeal. Careers and rights are at stake here as a result of bad or biased decisions by department heads.
I urge the government to act immediately to restore to Canadians the fair and effective appeal process they thought they had under the Canadian Security Intelligence Service Act and to introduce an amendment now.

Mr. Speaker, since 1974 the United Nations has passed some 24 resolutions calling on Thrkey to withdraw its troops from the independent state of Cyprus.
In 1990 the UN passed resolutions calling for Iraq to withdraw its troops from the independent state of Kuwait. In 1991 a coalition of UN forces, including Canada, enforced the UN Kuwait resolutions. After 18 years the UN Cyprus resolutions still have not been enforced.
Canada, the U.S. and all members of the UN-Kuwait coalition should be deeply embarrassed by this double standard. Canada must do everything in its power to bring about an immediate, peaceful and just solution to the Cyprus problem.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on May 1, a splendid exhibition of medals will begin a grand tour.
Veterans Affairs has brought together all the decorations for bravery that Canadians could win since the Northwest Field Force was formed. Now thousands of people will have an opportunity to see this important part of our heritage.

many of the highest decorations for bravery were awarded posthumously.

Mr. Speaker, I want to alert all Canadians receiving pensions from other countries that this government may once again be picking their pockets and it could be doing it illegally.
Canada has struck protocols with most other countries. Canadians should be aware that they may be eligible for a pension from their land of birth. I am not aware of the details of protocol agreements other than Italy-Canada.
The Italian government sends $270 million to Canada tax free each year and the Canadian government is taxing these pensions to the extreme. The most disturbing effect of this situation is that the Italian government has not yet ratified the agreement. Is the government in the habit of implementing tax legislation that has not been legally ratified? The two governments should seize the opportunity to renegotiate the unsigned agreement. action together in order to assist those Canadians who seek meaningful employment.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in the absence of the Minister of Finance, my question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister.
Today we were informed that the projections given a month ago by the Minister of Finance were totally wrong. In one month, the number of unemployed workers rose by 74,000, which means 2,000 for every day since the Minister of Finance brought down his budget, and this is seven days a week, including Saturdays and Sundays.
When will the government realize that last month's budget projections have so far been proven wrong, that projections for many sectors have become increasingly negative and that the time has come to implement an action program to create jobs, before this country is overcome by a climate of despair?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, naturally we were disappointed at the figures released today by Statistics Canada on the unemployment situation in Canada. It confirms what the Minister of Finance said in his budget.
April 10, 1992

If the hon. member took time to read the budget, the Minister of Finance said: "Real output in the fourth quarter of 1991 was flat or may have declined. Available evidence suggests this weakness is carried over into early 1992". In fact, the figures that came out today did confirm what the Minister of Finance said in his budget.
Having said that, the Minister of Finance in his budget made many proposals which are designed to encourage Canadians to improve the economy of this country. He enunciated those yesterday very clearly: reducing personal income tax; the home buyers purchase plan; steps to improve competitiveness in the manufacturing and processing sector; and improvements in research and development. He went on to list a number of things that were in his budget.
Those still pertain today. It will take time to get them into the economy, but will be very important for the future growth of this country.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is absolutely unbelievable that the minister would get up and say: "I am disappointed". He should have said the government was wrong. Everything it has done so far is not working. We have more than 1.5 million people in Canada who would like to have the dignity of earning a living and this government is doing nothing.
We made a proposition a month ago. The government took only half of it.
This week we had in this town the mayors of the biggest cities in Canada. In every town and city in Canada there are hundreds and thousands of projects ready to go. They are willing to start the work if the federal government would pay one-third of the costs and the provincial governments would be willing to pay one-third.
Why not come to your senses and accept the help of the municipalities who want to create jobs? That is what we need. We are fighting inflation. In the 1930s, there was no inflation; the interest rates were very low. There was a lot of misery and this is exactly where we are going with the inaction of this government.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Leader of the Official Opposition is entirely wrong. The government
Oral Questions
recognizes the requirements of this country and that is why it is putting $3.4 billion this year into training and that is why the first ministers in this country have agreed to take certain actions to help the economy.
I will remind my hon. friend, who says the provinces and the municipalities will just jump in with a couple of extra billion dollars of what the premier of the province of British Columbia said after the first ministers' conference and I quote: "But if you are expecting us to write cheques right now for instant throw money at the problem of 1.4 million people being unemployed, a lot of this is structural unemployment. It is going to take many years to undo. It is not going to happen quickly. We are not going to do that. We are not going to go back to trying to increase our deficits by making money available to deal with some of the things you have talked about. That has been tried in the past and it does not work".

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like the hon. minister to go to the 83,000 people in Vancouver and make that nonsensical statement.
It is important today to realize that something has to be done when we have more than 203,000 people in Montreal who are unemployed, 213,000 people in Toronto alone who are unemployed, 36,000 people in Quebec City who are unemployed, 40,000 people who are unemployed in Winnipeg, 47,000 people unemployed in Edmonton.
We have a government that says nothing, does not care, that will adjourn the House and does not want to recognize that it made a mistake. Every prediction it has made is absolutely wrong so far and we want a program of action before we have many more people unemployed.
Why not use some common sense and do something positive? People want to work. It is the government that is not working properly.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, after consultations throughout the country by the Minister of Finance and the Minister of State for Finance and Privatization, it was very obvious that certain recommendations were made by people from all walks of life, from ordinary Canadians in this country as to some of the solutions as to what we should be doing to get the economy going again.

April 10, 1992
Oral Questions
I will remind the hon. member that it is not just Canada that is having financial difficulties right now. Financial difficulties are being experienced around the world. Our largest trading partner is experiencing financial problems. That is one of the reasons that our economy is not going well. We are an exporting nation and we have been unable to export into markets to any great extent that have had these financial difficulties.
The Minister of Finance did take action in his budget. If the Leader of the Opposition was fair he would recognize that. The minister reduced personal income taxes. He introduced a home buyers purchase plan, which I understand the Leader of the Opposition supports. It was one of the suggestions that was made by him.
I can talk about the tax situation whether in manufacturing and processing.

Madam Speaker, I have a question for the Acting Minister of Finance.
The sharp jump in unemployment from 10.6 to 11.1 per cent in the one month since the budget means that the budget is a failure. It obviously does not go far enough.
Almost 75,000 more Canadians have lost their jobs since that budget. That is 2,000 people a day, two people a minute just since last February.
Why does the minister not admit the government's failure and take new action now to help Canadians get back to work? Why does he not do something now to stop this bleeding away of the Canadian economy?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we have done a number of things, and the hon. member knows that. He also knows that a budget brought in in February does not produce instant results in a month's time. If he were fair he would admit that to the Canadian people.
The hon. member knows that budgets take time to work through the economy and to give confidence to the Canadian people to start producing jobs. I remember the
hon. member asking for lower interest rates. Of course they dropped again 20 basis points yesterday, and they are in the area of the lowest interest rates we have had in some 20 years.
Inflation is low, so there is capacity now in the economy to lower interest rates further. That is one of the very strong efforts that this government has done to get those rates down and to keep them down, and we have been successful in doing that. Of course this will help the economy grow as this year goes on.

Madam Speaker, there has been a response to the government's budget. The unemployment rate went up last month in nine out of ten provinces. That is the response.
Ontario and Quebec had sharp increases. In Ontario major cities like Toronto and Windsor had sharp increases.
Why is the government so deaf to the cries of individual Canadians? Why does the minister not hear them pleading for government action to help them get back to work and not phoney TV ads wasting taxpayers' money? That is not the action they want. They want jobs. Why does he not do something about that right now?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, Canadian people understand that short-term make-work projects do not solve the economic problems of this country.
They know that we have to get the basics in place, and that is what is being done. Certainly they want jobs. We understand that and we want them to have jobs. That is why we are pursuing policies that will give them longterm, meaningful jobs.
That is why we are spending $3.4 billion this year in training and retraining. That is a tremendous amount of money for training and retraining in co-operation, I might say, with the provincial premiers who are co-operating in the training.
As Premier Harcourt pointed out in his comments, with the large unemployment and 300,000 jobs going begging in certain areas where we do not have the expertise, obviously our training has not been geared in the proper direction. That is what we are doing now in co-operation with the provinces.
April 10, 1992

Oral Questions

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Acting Minister of Finance.
Whatever the acting minister chooses to say about what Canadians do or do not understand, Canadians who are unemployed, their families and the communities they live in understand very well the devastating effects of this government's economic policies. Every day they get worse and today's over 11 per cent unemployment rate just confirms that not only is the budget a failure, the government is also a failure and it must take action now.
As families are being devastated, as communities are being devastated, how many more jobs lost, how many more families hurt, how many more communities devastated before this government will take some action?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I will repeat for the hon. leader of the New Democratic Party, who obviously did not listen to the answers earlier, that we have taken action.
The budget enunciates a number of them. I will repeat them for her just to refresh her memory. There are personal income tax cuts. There is a home buyers purchase plan which, by the way, has spurred the housing industry on. There are increasing home starts. There are increasing sales in homes. This is very encouraging. It is one of the industries that will help lead us out of these difficult economic times.
We have put in place adjustments to the manufacturing and processing industry. The industries have been hard hit during this recession and we have done something in the budget to help them.
The hon. member knows that these things do not happen overnight. For her to make the statement that because things do not happen in one month after the budget it is a failure, is totally incorrect.

Madam Speaker, yes, things do not happen overnight. It has taken since 1984 for this government to destroy the Canadian economy, destroy Canadian jobs, and devastate Canadian communities.

Madam Speaker, 76,000 jobs were lost in a single month. In Montreal, over 200,000 people are unemployed and 100,000 are on welfare. This means that poverty in Montreal is costing the country $600 million annually. And the minister still has the nerve to say things are getting better? Has the government no shame?
Something has to be done now to bring down the unemployment rate and create jobs. What does the government intend to do, not in two years but now, for Canada's unemployed?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, that was the same question she asked the first time.
I want to refer to a couple of points she said in her preamble that were incorrect. I do not think this minister or any minister in our government said that things were going well. We are going through a tough period of time as are other countries. We are all going through a tough period of time, but we have basics in place. All indicators, commissions and groups indicate that Canada is in the best position to come out of these difficult times, and that is what we are doing.
I repeat there are a number of items in the budget to help the economy go on. I might remind the hon. member who says that this government has led Canada to a tough economic situation that we had the fastest growth and job creation over a seven-year period of any OECD country. So what she says is totally wrong.

Madam Speaker, the acting minister also knows that we have the second highest rate of unemployment in the OECD countries. That is the result, the direct result of this government's high interest policies, the high dollar, and the Canada-
U.S. trade deal.
The minister mentioned earlier in his response to another question that the Canadian Jobs Strategy and training programs needed to be changed. The change that this government has made has been to cut the Canadian Jobs Strategy for the last number of years, $100 million in the last budget. This has had devastating

April 10,1992
Oral Questions
consequences for the employment equity programs of the Canadian Jobs Strategy.
This is reflected today in Canada's statistics when we see that women over 25 are the most adversely affected by these unemployment statistics and are followed very closely by the young people in our country who are also suffering because of unemployment.
It is clear this government's policies have created this situation. If the government is not willing to make things better, will the government at least stop making things worse?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
On the contrary, Madam Speaker, the government is not making things bad; the government is working to improve the situation.
The hon. member said that we have a high interest rate policy. It turns out we have the lowest interest rates we have had in this country in 20 years. The dollar is some five cents lower than it was a year ago and that has helped with exports.
Our trade has grown since the free trade agreement with the United States. Our trade surplus with the United States has grown. There are some things happening in the economy that are very good. It will take time to come out of this, but we are in a position to do it. We are confident that as this year wears on we will find that economic conditions will improve and employment will improve.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade.
Canada is experiencing a massive and alarming one-month jump in the unemployment rate in this country and this government's response, specifically this minister's response, is to launch a multimillion dollar advertising campaign to tell the people of Canada the "good news" about free trade.
Unemployment in Newfoundland today is 20.3 per cent. In my own riding it is 23.6 per cent.
I want to ask the minister of trade, the minister of propaganda, whether or not he is prepared to cancel the multimillion dollar advertising campaign telling Canadians that things are all right and whether he is prepared to face up to the reality of unemployment in Canada and
to use that money to create jobs in Newfoundland and across this country. People want the dignity of a pay-cheque, not the pablum from a propaganda campaign.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as my colleague has said, we are quite upset with the level of unemployment. We have taken a number of actions to deal with the unemployment problem.
In addition, we know that people are aware of success stories, people who are finding new markets and building new markets in other countries. What we want to do with this advertising program is to convey to Canadians that there are people who are achieving success. If that can motivate others to do the same sort of thing then they will create jobs as well.
Are we going to sit in this House of Commons and only talk about the negatives that are happening in the country and not about the fact that some statistics are moving in the right direction? Inflation is at 1.7 per cent, the real gross domestic product in January was up, interest rates are down to their lowest levels in many years, and the Canadian merchandise trade balance has increased steadily month by month since September. These are all positive elements which must be taken into account.
If all we talk about is the negative then everybody will think negative things and will not see the progress my hon. friend would like to see and we on this side of the House would like to see.

Madam Speaker, how can this minister fail to realize that Canadians want to put a roof over their heads. Some 1.5 million unemployed Canadians want to put food on the table. They do not want to fill their heads with phoney propaganda, spreading the good news in the face of the reality of a continued recession leading toward depression-type circumstances in Canada.
I plead with the minister, in the name of 11 per cent of the population who are unemployed. Will he cancel an insult, an intellectual insult, a multimillion dollar advertising campaign, and put that money to work putting Canadians back to work and give Canadians the dignity of a pay-cheque in the face of this deep and lingering recession?
April 10, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, let us put things in context. The economic circumstances today are better than they were in 1981-82, so my friend is misleading people when he says things are far, far worse.
He talked about the phoney program. What we are trying to achieve is to let Canadians know that there are successes. I have talked to people who are building business in other countries.
